title: Carbon market gives clearer rules on offsetting - FoodNavigator.com
summary: The article discusses the increasing scrutiny and backlash against carbon offsetting, with companies like Nestle and Leon moving away from using carbon credits. To address concerns about the quality of carbon credits, the Integrity Council for the Voluntary Carbon Market (ICVCM) has released a global benchmark and a Core Carbon Principles (CCP) label for high-quality credits, while the Voluntary Carbon Markets Integrity Initiative (VCMI) has introduced a Claims Code to guide companies on making credible environmental claims.

title: Two Direct-Air Carbon Removal Projects Set for $1.1B DOE Push - Engineering News-Record
summary: The US Department of Energy is awarding $1.1 billion to two companies, Occidental Petroleum and Battelle, to build direct-air carbon removal (DAC) hubs in Texas and Louisiana. These hubs, which will be the largest in the world, are designed to remove up to 1 million metric tons of CO2 per year from the atmosphere. The projects are part of a larger federal effort to support the development of DAC technology, which is seen as a key tool for achieving net-zero emissions by 2050.

title: Paving An Intentional Road To A Sustainable IT Future - The Next Platform
summary: The article highlights the environmental impact of e-waste generated by the rapidly evolving IT hardware industry. Lenovo's Asset Recovery Services (ARS) offers a sustainable solution for businesses by facilitating recycling and refurbishing of old IT equipment, helping them reduce their environmental footprint and comply with regulations. This service includes options for repurposing hardware, donating it to charities, and ensuring secure data disposal, providing businesses with a comprehensive and environmentally conscious approach to managing their IT hardware lifecycle.
